qas.question: Voters in the city approve which kind of amendment?
What kind of politics have been strong in the municipal government?
Ann Arbor became the 1st city in the US to what type of voting in the Mayoral race?

plausible_answers.text: lessened the penalties for possession of marijuana

qas.question: What charter amendment was approved in 1947?
Who was the first openly homosexual to win office in 1947?
What kind of voting did Ann arbor use in 1957?
What process was repealed in 1967 after use in only one election?
Who is the representative for Ann Arbor in the 21st congressional district?

context: <a1_0>Left-wing politics<a1_0/> have been particularly strong in municipal government since the 1960s. Voters approved <a0_0>charter<a0_0/> amendments that have <b3_0>lessened the penalties for possession of marijuana<b3_0/> (1974), and that aim to protect access to abortion in the city should it ever become illegal in the State of Michigan (1990). In 1974, <b4_0>Kathy Kozachenko<b4_0/>'s victory in an Ann Arbor city-council race made her the country's first openly homosexual candidate to win public office. In 1975, Ann Arbor became the first U.S. city to use <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>instant-runoff<a2_0/> voting<b6_0/><b5_0/> for a mayoral race. Adopted through a ballot initiative sponsored by the local Human Rights Party, which feared a splintering of the liberal vote, the process was repealed in 1976 after use in only one election. As of August 2009, Democrats hold the mayorship and all council seats. The left tilt of politics in the city has earned it the nickname "The People's Republic of Ann Arbor". Nationally, Ann Arbor is located in Michigan's 12th congressional district, represented by Democrat <b7_0>Debbie Dingell<b7_0/>.
